column1: ==Tolkien's Introductory Comments==

Tolkien noted that Waldman had asked for a brief sketch of his imaginary world.  He said it was difficult to say anything without saying too much: the attempt opened a floodgate of excitement.  The egoist and artist desired to unfold how it all had grown
column2: what it was like
column3: and what he was trying to mean or represent.  He would inflict some of this upon Waldman but then append a mere resumé of its contents.

column5: endowed with consistent linguistic style and an illusion of historicity

column2: 1937.</ref> it had been rewritten many times and all parts had been laboriously pondered (which was perhaps not a recommendation).  The point was that Tolkien said he could not substantially alter it
column3: it must stand or fall practically as it was.

column1: At this point in the letter a summary of ''The Lord of the Rings'' was written with no comments.
Although long
column2: the summary of ''The Lord of the Rings'' was a bald resumé.  He had not mentioned the [[Ents]].  Love-stories were in the tale
column3: wholly absent from ''The Hobbit''.  But the highest love-story
column4: of [[Aragorn]] and [[Arwen]] was only alluded to.  The "rustic" love of [[Samwise Gamgee|Sam]] and his [[Rose Cotton|Rosie]] is ''absolutely essential'' to the study of the chief hero's character
column5: and to the relationship of ordinary life to quests
column6: sacrifice
column7: and causes.

column1: But
column2: said Tolkien
column3: he would say no more.  Not much could be done to make ''The Lord of the Rings'' publishable if it was not so now.  ''The Hobbit'' had been revised to clarify [[Gollum]]'s character and relationship to the Ring
column4: which enabled Tolkien to shorten "[[The Shadow of the Past]]".  If material from ''The Silmarillion'' were published then background explanation
column5: such as in "[[The Council of Elrond]]" could be cut.

column1: As a last note Tolkien wondered if Waldman would ever read this letter.
